article.title: Multiparameter Behavioral Analyses Provide Insights to Mechanisms of Cyanide Resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans
article.abstract: Environmental toxicants influence development, behavior, and ultimately survival. The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has proven to be an exceptionally powerful model for toxicological studies.

sections.introduction: Environmental toxicants influence development, behavior, and ultimately survival. The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has proven to be an exceptionally powerful model for toxicological studies.
sections.methods: Caenorhabditis elegans strains were grown at 20Â°C, on standard Nutrient Growth Media (NGM) agarose plates with Escherichia coli OP50 bacterial food, as previously described (Brenner, 1974).
sections.results: Prior studies have shown that egl-9-deficient worms could survive concentrations of HCN gas that killed wild-type worms (Gallagher and Manoil, 2001).
sections.discussion: Overactivation of HIF-1, via loss-of-function mutations in egl-9, has been shown to impact C. elegans longevity and stress resistance (Powell-Coffman, 2010).

article.insights_summary: We developed novel technologies to describe the effects of cyanide toxicity with high spatiotemporal resolution and examined the genetic underpinnings of cyanide resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.
article.acknowledgments: The authors are grateful to Kyle Petersen, Justin Mai, and Richard Gibson for help in developing the GUI and worm tracking program, to Korinna Radke for editorial suggestions, and to Daniel Fortin for help with statistical analyses.
